repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Water Resources Sector
            Adjustment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Water Resources
            Sector Adjustment for Indonesia were as follows: the outcome
            was satisfactory, the sustainability was highly likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank performance was satisfactory, and the borrower
            performance was unsatisfactory. Lessons learned: difficult
            policy and institutional reforms, of the scope of WATSAL,
            require four conditions to be fulfilled. WATSAL provided
            balance-of-payments support against a negative list of
            expenditures instead of providing import support based on a
            positive list of eligible, sector-related imports as is more
            common for sector adjustment operations. Piloting of
            controversial or complex aspects of a reform program, prior
            to or during the loan period creates confidence and
            generates political support. From the perspective of Loan
            Performance, enactment of a law should be avoided, if
            possible, as common sense suggests. In the WATSAL case, the
            drafting of the law and the regulations was undertaken by an
            inter-agency and multi-disciplinary Task Force having NGO
            representation. For a major reform program, funding is
            needed for Task Force expenses. A multi-tranche sector
            reform takes time and requires higher than average Bank
            funding for supervision, and for communication and translations.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Water Resources Sector
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Water Resources Sector Adjustment
            Loan Project provides balance of payments assistance to
            Indonesia to support a structural adjustment program of
            policy, institutional, regulatory, legal, and organizational
            reforms in the management of water resources and the
            irrigation sector. The programs four objectives include: 1)
            facilitating efficient environmentally and socially
            sustainable water resources development and management by
            decentralization, activating intergovernmental sector
            management coordination, policy planning, issuing national
            regulations and guidelines and a data-sharing network; 2)
            strengthening the institutional and regulatory framework for
            integrated and equitable river basin management; 3)
            establishing effective regulatory institutions and
            implementation arrangements for water pollution abatement
            and regional water quality management; and 4) improving the
            performance and sustainability of irrigation systems by
            establishing an institutional framework for transparent and
            accountable delivery of irrigation services and
            participatory fiscal support to democratic farmer
            organizations empowered with governance and financial
            authority to manage irrigation networks under their control.
            The loan will be disbursed in three tranches.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Water Sector Adjustment Loan
            Project : sectoral environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This Sectoral Environmental Assessment
            (SEA) for the Water Sector Adjustment Loan describes the
            risks associated with Indonesia's policy reforms
            regarding water management, and it proposes mitigation
            options. The lack of transparency and accountability will be
            offset by encouraging nongovernmental organizations to act
            as permanent advisory members to the national apex body that
            will be established to address the overall weakness in
            implementing environmental regulations. The participation of
            stakeholders will also be increased through strengthening
            provincial and river basin water resources management
            agencies, committees, and units. To address water pollution,
            particularly urban pollution from household waste and
            agricultural chemicals, long-term programs of institutional
            and infrastructure development and training and promotion
            programs (e.g., integrated pest management and frequent
            media campaigns) will be installed. To allay concerns about
            the capacity of water users' associations to handle
            irrigation reform and the transfer of secondary canals, and
            about the varying patterns of community leadership between
            the regions, a recommendation was made to phase in these
            responsibilities while continuously reviewing and revising
            the transfer procedure.
